Body:
I'm trying to test my LoRaWAN network and I'm having some very disappointing results. I have a Ideetron lorank8v1 gateway which can work over distances of 15 km.

In addition I used the Ideetron Nexus Board as a microcontroller and a Nexus Demoboard where the sensors are mounted.

I'm sending 1 packet per minute with my humidity and temperature measurements.

After 200m my packets arenâ€™t captured by the gateway anymore. I've ran the packet logger software on my gateway and all packets that are captured have a bad CRC_CODE verification which I think is due to interference.

I have thought that I may have some interference from LTE/3G/4G networks but these networks are not 868MHz band in Greece.

My gateway has 8 simultaneous channels and my node uses SF9 with a 125KHz bandwidth. When I changed these parameters nothing changed. I'm using it in a urban area.

What should I do? Maybe I have to configure the datarate
column9:
the spreadingfactor and the frequencies at which my node transmits? Are there any better ideas out there?

"

Body: If SF12 with *max* TX/RX power does not work, it means that the LoRa cannot work in this situation.
@KostasTsakos I designed and developed a standalone LoRa application. In urban area (Vienna) I can reach maximum 200 meters with SF12 and 125 kHz bandwidth at 869 MHz. That's LoRa.
I have two parameteres, the one for the Tx and the other for the Rx,..for each one i choose tha channel and the SF. In both of them shoud i choose the SF12? Or they should have different?

You might try to have a look at the RX info, i.e. RSSI (signal strength) and SNR (noise level). They could give a hint what's wrong here, especially if you start in a short distance from the gateway with a working connection and successively go farther away. With a (_LoRaWAN_) The Things Network setup you could also do a mapping for better visualization.
Which spreading factor are you using now? And where did you use them, in rural area or urban area?
SF9 i have chosen with 125KHz bandwith...however i tried to change it and change also the frequency channels of mynode but i couldn't notice any difference. :/
And the same frequency channel or different?
Same. If you are using LoRa rather than LoRaWAN.
Please try to use SF12. Again, would you please tell me where did you use them, in rural area or urban area?
You should use same SF for them, e.g., SF12.
In a urban area! But i tried to mount my gateway at a high elevation! I will check for SF12...
@arminb sounds really odd that it performed so poorly in that situation as LoRa with its spread spectrum chirps should be excelling in those circumstances.
